column4: got a ext3 partition, 65GB used space but i only can see a 1,2MB file ...
`du -h --max-depth=1 /path/to/partition` will show you which directories hold the data.
du: Zugriff auf „/media/Ext3/Bilder“ nicht möglich: Eingabe-/Ausgabefehler
Don't do deutsch that well, so could you just pastebin the whole output from that command?
Okay, what if you add sudo in front of the command? And yes, please add what wols and theadmin just suggested.
http://pastebin.de/18126

Okay, as wols and theadmin suggested, you need to pastebin /var/log/syslog (not all of it, just the relevant parts) so that we can see what the kernel says when it mounts the drive and tries to use it.
There is data, but filesystem browser won't show it because of all the errors.
how do i know what relevant parts are?
All that has /media/Ext3 on it. You can do `grep \/media\/Ext3 /var/log/syslog`, but that might leave out something.
do i need to unmount the drive before i pastebin /syslog?
No.
Just add sudo in front.
sudo: /var/log/syslog: command not found
Either open the log file in an editor, like `gksudo gedit /var/log/syslog`, or use the grepping like `sudo grep Ext3 /var/log/syslog`.
http://pastebin.com/TUA7ivbd
reading the log tells ME nothing
It just tells us that the system can't read the medium correctly. Are you sure that the drive is alright, and it works flawlessly in some other machine?
i checked it on my netbook but there it doesnt even show me the small file
few days ago everything worked fine. While i was doing some backups the process crashed and now its like that
Then something went awry, and I don't know how to fix that. I'm sorry. Hope you get someone to help you further.
thanks anyway!
Keep that syslog pastebin entry handy, so that you can present that with the story of 'something went wrong while backuping', it will make a good starting point.
at least i now know what the drive contents
